A Review of the North Manchurian Plague Prevention Service
Reports (1918 - 1922)
by
H. McG. Robertson, Surgeon.

This interesting report is edited by Wu Lien Teh, M. A.,
M. D., B.C. (Cantab), Director and Chief Medical Officer of the North
Manchurian Plague Prevention Service, It seems that the province of
Manchuria had been practically free from plague of any type from the
time of the great pneumonic epidemic of 1910 and 1911 until the fall
of 1920. However, in Mongolia and Siberia between the periods just
mentioned plague had been reported present nearly every year. In 1911
5 bubonic cases were reported at Scharasone; in 1912 3 pneumonic cases
were reported in Chita; in 1913 some bubonic cases were reported in the
Kirghiz Steppes; in 1914 there were 16 bubonic cases in Transbiakalia;
in 1917 bubonic cases were recorded at Patsebelong in Mongolia, resulting
in the Shansi outbreak (pneumonic) with 16000 deaths; in 1919 2 bubonic
cases both fatal were reported at Ikievskaya. This brings the report
down to the 1920 and 1921 pneumonic epidemic. It seems that in August
of this year1920 there were 13 bubonic cases reported in Mongolia and Siberia
near the Manchurian border and that later, in October and November, there
were 8 bubonic cases found in Hailar, in northwestern Manchuria. Of
these 8 cases 6 presented the buboes in the arm pit or about the neck and
2 in the groin. In late November and to December 3, so called septic
cases were reported in Hailar. The disease spread as the pneumonic form
slowly, and during the winter caused 52 deaths in this city which has a
population of 10,000 people. From Hailar the disease spread in epidomic
form along the railways and other routes of travel in Manchuria as far
south as Harbin and as far east as Vladivostock, although cases were
reported still farther south in smaller numbers. In a population of
20,000,000 persons in Manchuria there were 9300 deaths including 600
Russians. The epidemic reached its height in February, 1921, and had
practically subsided by May 15, although in Vladivostock there were 48
deaths which occurred from pneumonic plague between June 15 and October 15.

It is gathered from this Report that practically all of the
human cases of bubonic plague seen in Asiatic Russia and northern China
are traceable to infection acquired through skinning the Siberian marmot
for its fur.

The editor makes the following statement as to the evolution
of this disease: “During our stay at Hailar we noted a gradual evolution
of the plague from the bubonic through the septicemic to the pneumonic
form, due principally to promiscuous spitting and huddling together of
coolies day and night in unvenitlated inns.”

It is interesting to note that while this pneumonic epidemic
is accredited as resulting from the bubonic form, that in Vladivostock
the bubonic form is reported at the end of this epidemic of 1921, there

being reported one human bubonic case and 5 infected rats in July, and
one human case and 2 infected rats on August 10. The occurrence of bubonic
cases during the winter months while the pneumonic epidemic was in force
was occasionally reported, though all but one of these are reported as
doubtful. The one positive bubonic case reported resulted from an infected
wound of the foot in one who presumably occupied quarters in which pneumonic
plague had been found. It is noted in the bubonic cases reported in the
beginning of this review that the dates of occurrence are not given except
those which occurred in 1920. These are all in August, October and early
November.

The author of this report, who was in charge of the preventive
measures instituted in the epidemic of 1920 and 1921, has this to state in
regard to therapeutic measures: “No form of treatment was found of any
avail”. He given a list of drugs given and measures taken to effect a cure
or amelioration but states: “They did not cure the patients nor did they
prolong life”. It is evidently the opinion of Dr. Teh that the mortality
of pneumonic plague is 100%. He says: “the prognosis is well nigh hopeless,
as no authentic case of pulmonary plague in either of the two great epidemics
has been known to survive.”

As an example of the number of patients sent to the plague
hospital at Harbin who must not have had plague, if the mortality is 100%,
it may be stated that of 227 cases only 178 were diagnosed as plague. Many
persons were sent to the plague hospital during the epidemic as suspocted
plague cases who upon observation were found to have some other disease, and
it is interesting to note that few of these non-plague cases thus admitted
to these hospitals developed the disease.

Pneumonic plague is rightly considered a disease which is highly
infectious and under certain circumstances of poor ventilation, overcrowding
and lack of proper precautionary measures it undoubtedly is. Yet the ex-
perience of the Director of this Service would indicate that it need not
necessarily be so.

The Director in comparing the experience of his own force of
workers in Manchouli with that of the local workers in this place, says:
“The Russians had 5 doctors, six nurses and 15 sanitary attendants on
their staff. Our Plague Service personnel consisted of three doctors and
four nurses among others. On the Russian side there died of plague 3 nurses
(one woman), 15 sanitary attendants and 1 police. We lostnone. The Russian
Sanitary Staff was mostly untrained and very careless about wearing masks in
the presence of the sick and dead. They smoked cigarettes while handling
the dead, drank more alcohol than was good for them and many were struck
down unnecessarily. It was a sad story.”

He further says, “The mortality among the sanitary squads was
high, especially in Dalainor where it reached 50%, - the highest figure
reached in the previous epidemic (1911). When comparing this high mortality
among the sanitary coolies with the clear record of our dressers one must
bear in mind the fact that the coolies were certainly more exposed to
infection than the dressers. Moreover, the dressers were more aware of the
danger and took care to follow the precautionary measures exactly.”

The practical measures given to prevent contracting the
disease are these: wear a mask and hood when going into the presence
of the sick (infection only comes through the nose and mouth; no antiseptics
are necessary for the mask); rinse mouth with warm thymol water afterwards;
rubber gloves, overalls, goggles and rubber boots are also to be worn and
are to be discarded, along with the mask and hood, on leaving the sick room.

In speaking of the infective period the editor says: “We can
say without hesitation that as a rule there is a non-infective period of
about 24 hours during which the patient has fever and quick pulse but no
cough or bloody expectoration. This is the time when he may be moved to
the hospital without danger to others.”

In regard to the dead he says: “Don't be afraid of dead bodies,
for once the sick cease to breathe the bacilli cannot escape from the body.
The danger from clothes of the newly dead is great”. “Such bodies should be
covered with lime or sprayed with a disinfectant”.

In speaking of the influenza epidemic in Harbin in the fall of
1918 this report says: “at least 10 to 20% of the population have been
attacked this autumn”. At this time Harbin must have had a population of
about 275,000 as in 1921 there were 300,000 persons in the city. There were
thus, at the least 27,000 cases of influenza in Harbin in the fall of 1918,
while the epidemic of pneumonic plague in the winter of 1920-21 resulted in
3125 deaths. The mortality is, of course, not comparable, but it is
interesting to compare in this way the infectiousness of the two diseases.
It may be said that the rapid spread of influenza and the almost total
inability to determine the source of the infection in any outbreak is in
strong contrast with the rather slow spread of pneumonic plague and the
relative cease of locating the person who introduced it into a locality and
his connection with some known focus of the disease. (Easy because the
patient always dies)

This ability to determine the source of infection is shown in
the following statements of the Director: “the first case (in Tsitsihar)
occurred in a petty shop assistant who escaped from Dalainor and lived in
the house of a friend who was later affected and died”; also, “The first
plague case in Harbin was recorded on January 22, when an ex-miner died
suddenly in a house near the hospital after having arrived from Delainor
the day before. In a small village four miles from the City another miner
from Delainor died on January 26.”

It is stated in the chapter of this book which deals with the
influenza epidemic, that in Harbin “among Russians (exclusive of jews)
eighty to ninety persons have died of influenza on its after effects from
October 1 to November 10, 1918.” From this it will be gathered that
influenza did not need for its spread the marked overcrowding seen in
the Chinese coolie population, which contributed so materially to tho
spread of the pneumonic plague epidemic. In this plague epidemic only
600 Russians died in the whole of Manchuria.

It remains to mention some laboratory experiments made as to
the viability of the bacillus pestis under differing circumstances. This
viability was tested by exposing the sputum under different conditions of

sunlight and temperature, and when exposed along in petri dishes, mixed with
earth or exposed on various articles of furniture or clothing.

The outstanding observations along this line are probably not
new. They are:
1. that the bacillus pestis cannot be cultivated from dried sputum
after 21 hours in diffused daylight if exposed on a petri dish
at a temperature of 12 degrees C.=53.6°F
2. in an unheated room, exposed to diffused daylight at a temper-
ature of 3 degrees C. (37.4 degrees F.), cultures are found
negative at the end of the 96 hours.
3. sputum exposed on gauze in the corner of a slightly heated room
was sterile at the expiration of 96 hours.
4. sputum exposed on earth in shady corner of a slightly heated
room was negative after 8 hours.
5. Sputum mixed with or covered by earth showed a “few” plague
organisms at the end of 12 hours, at a laboratory temperature
of 17 degrees centigrade. It is stated that these experiments
were “purposely discontinued” at the end of 12 hours. It would
be interesting to know if such earth would not have been entirely
free from plague organisms at the end, say, of 96 hours. This
might have given a rather good idea of the possible length of
time that the floors of the Manchurian houses could retain the
infection.

It may be mentioned that dry sputum in an icebox and in
ice cellars (“artificial cold”) were negative only after 208 days.

Another experiment made by this service had to do with the
length of time which plague might exist in a Siberian marmot, or
tarabagan as they are called, under the condition of hibernation. It
is stated in this report that in 1911 Dujardin-Beaumetz and Mosny
inoculated 3 hibernating marmots with bacillus pestis. One of these died
soon after; the two others survived for 61 and 115 days respectively,
showing “enormous numbers of plague bacilli in their organs”. Others
report similar results and this Service mentions one marmot dying after
6 months. It is the opinion of the director that “subacute or chronic
plague may exist among the tarabagans (marmots) in Siberia and Mongolia
and thus form a connecting link in the epidemiology of the disease”. The
Director states, in this connection, that the Indian Plague Commission had
“twice stated that the chronic (resolving) form of rat plague could not
become acute”.
Note.

In view of certain opinions expressed by me recently as to
the reasons for the absence or practical absence in human beings, of
bubonic plague in cold countries, I may be pardoned for making a
personal comment on the subject considered in the last paragraph of
this review. It seems to me that the Director of the Manchurian Plague
Prevention Service and the Indian Plague Commission may both be right,
their views being reconciled by the different habits of the rat and the
Siberian marmot. The latter animal begins its hibernation in November and
emerges in May, with possibly longer periods in this condition - depending
upon the weather. It is the habit of the marmot to burrow deeply into
the ground and carry into the depths of his retreat a quantity of dried
grass. Upon going into winter quarters the entrance to the burrow is
closed and the entire family - male, female and the summers brood -
dispose themselves in a pile beneath the hay to pass away the winter
months in a state of “suspended animation”. The rat does not hibernate
nor does he lay up food for the winter months. It is thus necessary for
him even in the cold season to be out in the open in search of food. In
cold countries he will in this way lose his fleas and the next in which
he sleeps will probably not be heavily infested if at all. There is also
the probability that in an active animal only such lesions as chronic
“buboes” can last for a period of any great length, the septicemic cases
dying out in a relatively short time. Thus possibly the bacillus pestis
is not in the circulating blood of this animal and the spread of the
disease would be unlikely. In the marmot on the other hand we are told
that at the end of several months “enormous numbers of plague bacilli are
found in the organs”, in which case the bacilli will probably be in the
peripheral circulation.

It is possible that the marmot takes with it into its winter
burrow adult fleas. These may not only survive the winter but may
multiply in the dried grass under which the hibernating animal has
ensconsed itself. If this is so it is highly probable that a marmot which
after several months of hibernation has “enormous numbers of plague
bacilli in its organs”, and its fur possibly teeming with adult fleas
can give rise in the “summer colonies” of these animals to an epidemic of
bubonic plague and in this way perpetuate the disease from year to year.
This could hardly happen in a rat population where the cold reduced the
number of fleas below the number necessary to keep the disease alive (over
this winter in Cool or Cold countries).

To one uninitiated into the deeper mysteries of bacteriology
and into the possibilities of continuing infection in hibernating animals,
it is hardly conceivable that the infecting organism would not die out
or lose its virulence or that the infected animal would live thus for
months with its organs teeming with plague bacilli. Yet such seems to be
the case.

It would be interesting to note the temperature at the depth
of the marmots' burrows in mid-winter and to ascertain if fleas are found
on these animals when they emerge from their burrows at the end of the
hibernating period; and if so to compare the number in the spring with the
number found at the beginning of the hibernating period.
